item.title: Zomg my first c++ program! zomgzomg
item.dc:creator: @Cheesehunk Cheesehunk
item.description:
@Cheesehunk wrote:

My first C++ Program is like yours, but I think mines better…

[code]#include

using namespace std;

int main()
{
int thisisanumber;

cout<<“Please Enter a number: “;
cin>> thisisanumber;
cin.ignore();
if (thisisanumber == 3) {
cout<<“You picked the best number ever!!\n”;
}
else if (thisisanumber>0) {
thisisanumber = thisisanumber* 2;
cout<<“You entered: “<< thisisanumber <<”\n”;
thisisanumber = thisisanumber/2;
cout<<”…Just kidding, you entered: “<< thisisanumber <<”\n”;
}

else if(thisisanumber<0) {
cout<<“Don’t be so Negative!=P\n”;
}

else {
cout<<“You have to be joking, who enters 0 as a number”;
}
cin.get();
}[/code]

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

How would a clone of Swiftswitch written in C++ automatically be better than a VB one?

Aside from the memory leaks, which could be fixed while still using VB.

item.source: Zomg my first c++ program! zomgzomg

item.title: Zomg my first c++ program! zomgzomg
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

nice work man. I got a C book but I haven’t cracked it open yet. I’m eager to learn, but lazy haha.

If only someone made a RuneScape browser in C++. It would be so much more efficient that SwiftSwitch which was made in VB. Maybe Mopar and the rest of the people could help make a browser just like SwiftSwitch but 10 times better and do the same thing that MoparScape did which was turn off all those macro traps and stuff like that. There is an idea!

SwiftSwitch also has a few memory leaks… Glad I stopped helping them.

Read full topic

item.title: Zomg my first c++ program! zomgzomg
item.dc:creator: @ThE_ViKinG ThE ViKinG
item.description:
@ThE_ViKinG wrote:

void MoveMouseSmooth(int x, int y, int steps) { Point cureent; while (steps > 0) { GetCursorPos(cureent); int diffx = (x - cureent.X) / steps; int diffy = (y - cureent.Y) / steps; if (diffx != 0 || diffy != 0) { SetCursorPos(cureent.X + diffx, cureent.Y + diffy); Wait(1); } steps--; } }
LOL

item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

1337h4x: if you’re going to use functions like cout and cin much, try adding this after the #include block:

using namespace std;

so you wont have to type std::cout instead of cout

item.dc:creator: @1337h4x 1337h4x
item.description:
@1337h4x wrote:

Thats right people,

languages 1337h4x[] = new langueges[];
1337h4x[1] = "Html";
1337h4x[2] = "JavaScript";
1337h4x[3] = "Java"; // <3<3
1337h4x[4] = "PHP";
1337h4x[5] = "C++";

I started learning C++…heres my ownege new program XD

[code]// HelloKirill.cpp : Defines the entry point for the console application.
//

#include “stdafx.h”

#include

int _tmain(int argc, _TCHAR* argv[])
{
int n1 = 0;
int n2 = 0;
//for (int i=0; i<10; i++)
//{
// std::cout << "Hello " << i << std::endl;
//}
//f = std::cin << "Enter a number. " << std::endl;
std::cout << "Enter a number: ";
std::cin >> n1;
std::cout << "Enter a second number: ";
std::cout >> n2;
std::cout << "You entered " << n1 << std::endl;

std::cout << std::endl << std::endl << "Press enter";

char szBuffer[10];
std::cin >> szBuffer;
return 0;

}
[/code]
